awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: cis-Regulatory Basis of Butterfly Wing Pattern Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description
Understanding the formation of color patterns has long played a central theme in understanding biology.  Butterfly wing color patterns represent a prime model to explore the history, genes, and mechanisms underlying wing patterning. A single gene (WntA) drives shape changes across the wing surface in many distantly related species, thus suggesting a fundamental and ancestral function in butterfly wing formation.  The research team from the University of Puerto Rico, George Washington University, and Cornell University will investigate the gene changes underlying distribution of pigmentation across the wing surface among a variety of butterfly species. The goal of the study is to determine how WntA has acquired the ability to control diverse wing displays across multiple time scales. This study will set the foundation for understanding the interplay between gene regulation and diversity of form. 

Technical description
This study aims to determine how gene regulatory architecture evolves in concert with an adaptive trait over different time scales. The research team will specifically focus on characterizing the regulatory mechanisms underlying the repeated role of the signaling ligand WntA in wing pattern evolution. This work will address how the modulation of WntA spatial expression has tinkered with the micro- and macroevolution of distinct wing phenotypes across 65 million years. We will specifically aim to address the following questions: (1) How many regulatory elements at a single gene control wing pattern variation, and what are the function of individual elements? (2) Do the same elements also control the convergent evolution of mimetic phenotypes in unrelated species? (3) To what extent are wing pattern CREs conserved versus novel across species with highly divergent wing patterns? Answering these questions will help set a precedent for understanding deeper phylogenetic patterns in the relationship between the evolution of CREs and the traits they define. Finally, this research project will synergize with educational opportunities spanning pre-college, undergraduate, and post-graduate levels of science education. The research work of our three groups will directly involve undergraduate researchers and the training of two postdocs.

por.por_cntn:
Butterflies have emerged as prominent subjects for investigating the intricacies of phenotypic variation in terms of evolution and development. In this proposal we have focused predominantly on a group of incredibly diverse tropical butterflies named Heliconius, which are renowned for their aposematic wing color patterns that serve as clear signals to predators, indicating their unpalatability. These distinctive signals are subject to intense selective pressures and it's common to find multispecies from separate lineages that have independently evolved to converge on the same protective phenotype, allowing them to collectively benefit from the learning process of their avian predators. Such a remarkable divergence within and convergence between species in the patterns of wing coloration has fueled extensive genetic research spanning several decades. Nevertheless, the challenge of bridging the genetic patterns of diversification with the precise molecular mechanisms of adaptation has, until recently, remained elusive.

In this project through the utilization of cutting-edge techniques in developmental genetics and functional genomics, we have initiated the process of uncovering the intricate relationship between color pattern genes and the specific regulatory variants responsible for shaping wing phenotypes. Consequently, the incorporation of developmental, functional, and comparative genomic methodologies within a group of diverse butterfly species has provided an insightful glimpse into the mechanisms governing phenotypic diversity. With this project, we have made significant progress in connecting the genome to function, leading to a more profound understanding of the genetic underpinnings of morphological diversification. While, only a small number of genes with substantial effects were initially identified as contributors to the diversification of color patterns in butterflies, we have been able to unveil the intricate gene regulatory networks and their evolutionary transformations. These findings, published in top peer-review scientific journals, uncover an evolutionary narrative characterized by numerous interacting genetic loci and partially independent genetic structures, all of which play pivotal roles in the process of divergent and convergent evolution of the vast array of pattering and colors on butterflies’ wings. Furthermore, with our work we have initiated the examination of previously formulated hypotheses regarding the developmental foundations of the mechanisms behind morphogenetic and transcriptional regulator signals in wing pattern evolution.

Our proposal has also been influential in the realm of science education, benefiting students at various levels, from pre-college to post-graduate. High school programs and academic laboratory teaching modules have integrated butterflies as a practical system for genome editing training. Additionally, the research has impacted numerous minority undergraduates, graduate students, and two postdoctoral researchers, contributing to a diverse and inclusive scientific community. Furthermore, this project has generated valuable resources for the broader scientific community, including the assembly of several new functionally annotated butterfly genomes, transcriptomes, and chromatin landscapes in wing and head tissues. These resources offer essential tools for researchers investigating a wide range of topics related to butterflies and other organisms. Most notably, this research serves as a compelling case study for the application of cutting-edge methods in chromatin footprinting and genome editing to study the regulatory evolution of adaptive traits in emerging model systems. It demonstrates how innovative techniques can be used to explore the mechanisms that drive the evolution of traits that enhance the survival and adaptation of species. Overall, this work has significantly advanced our understanding of the genetic and molecular basis of wing pattern diversity in butterflies and has had a substantial impact on both scientific knowledge and science education.
